title: 106_hr4248
content: The Act titled "Working And Reacting (WAR) Against Meth Act of 2000" addresses the manufacturing and distribution of amphetamine. The "Working And Reacting (WAR) Against Meth Act of 2000" addresses the manufacture and distribution of substantial and lesser quantities of amphetamine under the Controlled Substances Act. The Act specifies the quantities of amphetamine and its derivatives that constitute criminal offenses. The "Working And Reacting (WAR) Against Meth Act of 2000" defines criminal offenses related to the manufacture and distribution of specific quantities of amphetamine and its derivatives under the Controlled Substances Act. The Act includes provisions for quantities of amphetamine that constitute criminal offenses, such as 5 grams or more of amphetamine or 50 grams or more of a mixture containing amphetamine. SEC. 3. Import and export of amphetamine. Amendments are made to the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act regarding the import or export of substantial quantities of amphetamine. This includes specifying the quantities of amphetamine or its mixtures that would constitute a violation. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act specify that possessing 5 grams or more of amphetamine or 50 grams or more of a mixture containing amphetamine is a violation. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act specify that possessing certain amounts of controlled substances is a violation. Additionally, endangering human life or the environment while illegally manufacturing controlled substances is prohibited. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Act now include harm to the environment as a punishable offense, specifically for methamphetamine-related activities. Additionally, penalties are enhanced for establishing illegal manufacturing operations. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Act now include harsher penalties for methamphetamine-related activities, with a maximum imprisonment of 40 years and fines according to title 18, United States Code. Any violation that also breaches section 416 incurs additional penalties. Conduct related to the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine is presumed to be illegal. The conduct is presumed to create a substantial risk of harm to human life or the environment. SEC. 5. NATIONAL CENTER FOR METHAMPHETAMINE CLANDESTINE LABORATORY INFORMATION. The Attorney General directs the El Paso Intelligence Center (EPIC) and the Los Angeles County Regional Criminal Information Clearinghouse to form the National Center for Methamphetamine Clandestine Laboratory Information. EPIC's database will collect nationwide data on clandestine lab seizures, analyzed by the LA Clearinghouse and shared with law enforcement. $2,300,000 is authorized annually for this purpose until 2004.
